articles.headline: G.M. Decides to Keep Opel, Its European Unit
articles.snippet: The decision was a blow to the Canadian auto supplier Magna, which was poised to acquire a 55 percent stake in Opel with the backing of the German government and labor unions.
articles.abstract: The decision was a blow to the Canadian auto supplier Magna, which was poised to acquire a 55 percent stake in Opel with the backing of the German government and labor unions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The new board of General Motors reversed course Tuesday on the planned sale of its Opel division in Europe and decided that G.M. would retain and reorganize the business itself.

articles.headline: China Approves Disney Theme Park in Shanghai
articles.snippet: A resort, one of the largest-ever foreign investments in China, would cover 1,000 acres and cost $3.5 billion.
articles.abstract: A resort, one of the largest-ever foreign investments in China, would cover 1,000 acres and cost $3.5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  After a courtship of about 20 years, the Walt Disney Company has won approval from the central government of China to build a Disneyland-style theme park in Shanghai, Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive, said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Health Bills Aim a Light on Doctors’ Conflicts
articles.snippet: Proposals under consideration in Congress would require an online database showing the payments to doctors made by drug and device makers.
articles.abstract: Proposals under consideration in Congress would require an online database showing the payments to doctors made by drug and device makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As part of the health care overhaul under consideration by Congress, lawmakers have included so-called sunshine provisions intended to shed light on the financial relationships between the medical industry and doctors.

articles.headline: Through a Glass Less Darkly
articles.snippet: When an economy is just coming out of recession, its weaknesses are always more obvious than its potential strengths.
articles.abstract: When an economy is just coming out of recession, its weaknesses are always more obvious than its potential strengths.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1982, with a long recession ending but the unemployment rate heading toward 10 percent, The New York Times ran an article titled “The Recovery That Won’t Start.”

articles.headline: Iraq Swears by Bomb Detector U.S. Sees as Useless
articles.snippet: Iraqi security forces at hundreds of checkpoints have been relying on a hand-held wand.
articles.abstract: Iraqi security forces at hundreds of checkpoints have been relying on a hand-held wand.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Despite major bombings that have rattled the nation, and fears of rising violence as American troops withdraw, Iraq’s security forces have been relying on a device to detect bombs and weapons that the United States military and technical experts say is useless.

articles.headline: Buffett Bets Big on Railroads’ Future
articles.snippet: In buying Burlington Northern Santa Fe, Warren E. Buffett is hoping that the demand for shipping by train will remain strong or even grow.
articles.abstract: In buying Burlington Northern Santa Fe, Warren E. Buffett is hoping that the demand for shipping by train will remain strong or even grow.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s best-known investor, Warren E. Buffett, is making his biggest bet yet on the nation’s economic future by buying, of all things, a railroad.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: A Pentagon Contract Revives Jobs at Oshkosh
articles.snippet: Oshkosh’s off-road armored truck is proving to be worth billions of dollars for the company and a potential lifesaver for troops in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Oshkosh’s off-road armored truck is proving to be worth billions of dollars for the company and a potential lifesaver for troops in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSHKOSH, Wis.  United States Patent No. 5,820,150, for a particular design of independent truck suspension, is just one of the dozens of patents the Oshkosh Corporation has filed in recent years. But as the military shifts its focus to Afghanistan from Iraq, that single invention is proving to be worth billions of dollars to the company and a potential lifesaver for American troops in Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Picked From a Lineup, on a Whiff of Evidence
articles.snippet: Procedures in which dogs choose a suspect’s smell out of a group are under fire.
articles.abstract: Procedures in which dogs choose a suspect’s smell out of a group are under fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  A dog’s sniff helped put Curvis Bickham in jail for eight months. Now that the case against him has been dropped, he wants to tell the world that the investigative technique that justified his arrest smells to high heaven.

articles.headline: In October, Signs of Life at Retailers
articles.snippet: Some analysts are now predicting higher levels of holiday spending this season than last.
articles.abstract: Some analysts are now predicting higher levels of holiday spending this season than last.
articles.lead_paragraph: October was far and away the best month American retailers have had since consumers put the brakes on spending last autumn. Major categories had robust sales growth for the first time in more than a year, new figures show.
